question.para: Recall that the projection of a vector \Vect{x} in \RNr[n] onto the line L through the origin and in the direction of the nonzero vector \Vect{y} is
Which of the following is true?

answer.para: This projection is a real number.

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a real number.’
info.para:
Sorry! No! – If n > 1, and you project a vector on a line, you get .... ? – If n=1this projection is what?
a number, namely the original number x

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a vector’
info.para: Correct! – The projection of \Vect{x} onto L is a multiple of the vector \Vect{y}.

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a line’
info.para: No! - We start with a vector \Vect{x}, and projecting it onto a line L yields a single vector, contained in L.

question.para: If \proj_{L}(\Vect{x}) = 0 , what can you conclude about \Vect{x} in relation to the line L?

info.caption: Comment on: \Vect{x} = \Vect{0}
info.para: If \Vect{x} = \Vect{0}, its projection onto L will be the 0-vector. However, in general, this is not the reason why \proj_{L}(\Vect{x}) = \Vect{0}.

answer.para: I conclude that \Vect{x} lies on L

info.caption: Comment on: \Vect{x} lies on L
info.para: Sorry, no! If \Vect{x} lies on L, its projection onto L will be \Vect{x} itself.

answer.para: I conclude that \Vect{x} is perpendicular to L.

info.caption: Comment on: \Vect{x} is perpendicular to L
info.para: Correct! – Given that \Vect{y}\neq \Vect{0}, \proj_{L}(\Vect{x})=\Vect{0} exactly when \Vect{x} \bullet \Vect{y} = 0. This happens exactly when \Vect{x} is perpendicular to \Vect{y}.

problem.para: Verify that the given two lines in \RNr[3] are parallel. Then find the distance between them.

answer.para: The distance between the two parallel planes H_1 and H_2 is \tfrac{\sqrt{6} }{ 18 }.

solution.hint.para: Find normal vectors of H_1 and H_2.
The normal vectors of H_1 and H_2 are \Vect{n}_1=(1,1,-2) and \Vect{n}_2=(3,3,-6). – Check if they are parallel.
So the normal vectors are parallel. Therefore the planes are parallel.
The planes are not equal as \Vect{0} lies on H_1 but not on H_2.
So the distance between H_1 and H_2 is the distance from \Vect{0} to H_2.
